headline: How Media Outlets on the Right and Left Explained Trump’s Win
abstract: Media outlets on the right said Mr. Trump won because of the left’s embrace of what they called extreme political views. Left-leaning outlets offered a broader variety of explanations.
lead_paragraph: Media outlets across the political spectrum offered very different explanations about why Donald J. Trump won the presidential election this week.
snippet: Media outlets on the right said Mr. Trump won because of the left’s embrace of what they called extreme political views. Left-leaning outlets offered a broader variety of explanations.

headline: Residents Return to Find Homes Reduced to Rubble After California Fire
abstract: The Mountain fire has torn through more than 20,000 acres and destroyed more than 130 structures in Ventura County. “It’s just devastating,” one resident said.
lead_paragraph: In the city of Camarillo, Calif., on Old Coach Drive, the smell of smoke lay heavy in the air. The fire that erupted this week had hopscotched around the neighborhood, leaving some homes relatively unscathed but reducing several to charred piles of wood and rubble.
snippet: The Mountain fire has torn through more than 20,000 acres and destroyed more than 130 structures in Ventura County. “It’s just devastating,” one resident said.

headline: San Francisco Mayor-Elect Plans to Declare Fentanyl Emergency on Day 1
abstract: Daniel Lurie held his first news conference since Mayor London Breed conceded the mayoral race this week.
lead_paragraph: Daniel Lurie is a man in a hurry.
snippet: Daniel Lurie held his first news conference since Mayor London Breed conceded the mayoral race this week.

headline: As Trump’s New Term Looms, Hochul Considers Reviving Congestion Pricing
abstract: Gov. Kathy Hochul, facing pressure from supporters of the contentious tolling plan, is said to be exploring options for adopting it in some form.
lead_paragraph: Gov. Kathy Hochul of New York is exploring options for reviving a congestion pricing plan for New York City before President-elect Donald J. Trump has a chance to kill it, according to four people familiar with the matter.
snippet: Gov. Kathy Hochul, facing pressure from supporters of the contentious tolling plan, is said to be exploring options for adopting it in some form.

headline: Walz Offers Hope to Minnesota in Concession Speech
abstract: Gov. Tim Walz, the former vice presidential candidate, gave a concession speech in his home state on Friday, in which he vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”
lead_paragraph: Gov. Tim Walz, the former vice presidential candidate, gave a concession speech in his home state on Friday, in which he vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”
snippet: Gov. Tim Walz, the former vice presidential candidate, gave a concession speech in his home state on Friday, in which he vowed to “stand ready to stand up and fight.”

headline: Trump Weighs Key Personnel Choices, Schooled by His First-Term Experience
abstract: The president-elect held his first formal transition meetings and has been given lists of candidates, but is calling around to friends and allies for ideas.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump is not known for adherence to a disciplined and rigorous personnel selection process, but behind the scenes his advisers and allies have been preparing lists of candidates for the most important jobs in his administration.
snippet: The president-elect held his first formal transition meetings and has been given lists of candidates, but is calling around to friends and allies for ideas.

headline: Dorothy Allison, Author of ‘Bastard Out of Carolina,’ Dies at 75
abstract: She wrote lovingly and often hilariously about her harrowing childhood in a working-class Southern family, as well as about the violence and incest she suffered.
lead_paragraph: Dorothy Allison, who wrote with lyrical, pungent wit about her working-class Southern upbringing — and about the incest and violence that shaped her — and whose acclaimed 1992 novel, “Bastard Out of Carolina,” based on her harrowing childhood, made her a literary star, died on Wednesday at her home in Guerneville, Calif., in Sonoma County. She was 75.
snippet: She wrote lovingly and often hilariously about her harrowing childhood in a working-class Southern family, as well as about the violence and incest she suffered.

headline: Corrections: Nov. 9, 2024
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 9, 2024.
lead_paragraph: An article on Page 2 this weekend misstates the title of a song by the band Lankum. It is “Go Dig My Grave” not “I Dig My Grave.”
snippet: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, Nov. 9, 2024.

headline: The Long Global Trail of Resentment Behind Trump’s Resurrection
abstract: Disillusionment with the world that emerged from the Cold War has fueled a long-gathering revolt against the established order.
lead_paragraph: As the Cold War wound down almost four decades ago, a top adviser to the reformist Soviet leader, Mikhail S. Gorbachev, warned the West that “we are going to do the most terrible thing to you. We are going to deprive you of an enemy.”
snippet: Disillusionment with the world that emerged from the Cold War has fueled a long-gathering revolt against the established order.

headline: Democrats Consider an Autopsy, but Who’s the Coroner?
abstract: The Democratic Party agrees it needs to figure out what went wrong. The question is how.
lead_paragraph: After suffering what could shape up to be their biggest electoral defeat in more than 40 years, Democrats agree on one thing: They need to figure out what went wrong.
snippet: The Democratic Party agrees it needs to figure out what went wrong. The question is how.

headline: Spill
abstract: Chandi Deitmer and Hoang-Kim Vu’s Saturday collaboration might make solvers take a tumble or two.
lead_paragraph: SATURDAY PUZZLE — This is an unusual phenomenon, as there aren’t many themeless collaborations in Times puzzles. It’s also Chandi Deitmer’s Saturday debut, after six winsome Sundays over the last few years. Hoang-Kim Vu, her collaborator on today’s Crossword, has created a handful of weekend themeless grids. I spent three quarters of my solve in a charmed state: What zingy slang! What clever crosses! Then I spent 25 percent in white-knuckled suspense: Am I going to have to peek at this answer key? Is ordering Indian tonight cheating?
snippet: Chandi Deitmer and Hoang-Kim Vu’s Saturday collaboration might make solvers take a tumble or two.

headline: Brush Fire in Brooklyn’s Prospect Park Burns 2 Acres
abstract: The fire drew almost 100 firefighters, the commissioner said. The cause was not immediately determined.
lead_paragraph: About 100 firefighters were called to put out a two-acre brush fire in a heavily wooded section of Prospect Park in Brooklyn on Friday night, prompting officials to warn residents to stay away as they used drones to identify hot spots.
snippet: The fire drew almost 100 firefighters, the commissioner said. The cause was not immediately determined.

headline: Seattle Police Arrest Man in Connection With Five Stabbings
abstract: Five people were injured in attacks in the city’s Chinatown-International District on Friday, the police said.
lead_paragraph: A man was arrested in connection to stabbings that injured five people on Friday in Seattle, according to the local authorities.
snippet: Five people were injured in attacks in the city’s Chinatown-International District on Friday, the police said.

headline: Quote of the Day: For Harris, Star Endorsements Didn’t Shine as They Used To
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 9, 2024
lead_paragraph: “She couldn’t get the endorsement of the Teamsters, but she got the endorsement of Hollywood. That’s a tough message for a lot of voters.”
snippet: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, November 9, 2024

headline: Smile, Flatter and Barter: How the World Is Prepping for Trump Part II
abstract: Foreign leaders have rushed to ingratiate themselves with Donald J. Trump in recent days, nervously recalling the clashes, insults and feuds of his first presidency.
lead_paragraph: When Prime Minister Keir Starmer met Donald J. Trump at Trump Tower for dinner on Sept. 26, it was part of a British charm offensive to nurture a relationship between a left-wing leader and a right-wing potential president. So when Mr. Trump turned to Mr. Starmer before parting and told him, “We are friends,” according to a person involved in the evening, it did not go unnoticed.
snippet: Foreign leaders have rushed to ingratiate themselves with Donald J. Trump in recent days, nervously recalling the clashes, insults and feuds of his first presidency.

headline: Jacky Rosen Holds Off Sam Brown in Nevada, Keeping a Democratic Senate Seat
abstract: Ms. Rosen, the low-key incumbent, hung on, but the race was closer than expected amid President-elect Donald J. Trump’s strength.
lead_paragraph: Senator Jacky Rosen, a Democrat, will hang on to her Nevada Senate seat, according to The Associated Press, narrowly defeating her Republican opponent, Sam Brown.
snippet: Ms. Rosen, the low-key incumbent, hung on, but the race was closer than expected amid President-elect Donald J. Trump’s strength.

headline: Trump Wins Nevada, Flipping a Battleground State
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory in Nevada was the first for Republicans in a presidential election since 2004.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has won Nevada, according to The Associated Press, flipping a battleground state Republicans had not won since 2004.
snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory in Nevada was the first for Republicans in a presidential election since 2004.

headline: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
lead_paragraph: Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below.
snippet: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

headline: Trump’s Deportation Vow Fuels Fear and a Potential Showdown in New York
abstract: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has vowed to prevent mass deportations, but migrants and immigration lawyers are preparing for them.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump’s victory this week spread fear and panic across New York City’s more than 400,000 undocumented immigrants as they braced for the impact of one of his central campaign promises: a mass deportation program.
snippet: Mayor Eric Adams of New York City has vowed to prevent mass deportations, but migrants and immigration lawyers are preparing for them.

headline: How an Off Broadway Drag Show Choreographer Spends His Sundays
abstract: Spencer Liff, who choreographed “Drag: The Musical,” searches for New York’s best Bloody Mary, stops by the theater and tries to find his next great jacket at the flea market.
lead_paragraph: Before Spencer Liff returned to New York this summer to direct and choreograph the Off Broadway show “Drag: The Musical,” he spent 10 years in Los Angeles as a resident choreographer for “So You Think You Can Dance.”
snippet: Spencer Liff, who choreographed “Drag: The Musical,” searches for New York’s best Bloody Mary, stops by the theater and tries to find his next great jacket at the flea market.

headline: Gazans Are Living Through a Yearlong Blackout
abstract: Israel cut off electricity in the first days of the war, leaving Palestinians to light the dark with cellphones and to cook over open flames.
lead_paragraph: Mariam Abu Amra’s six children panic when the sun goes down.
snippet: Israel cut off electricity in the first days of the war, leaving Palestinians to light the dark with cellphones and to cook over open flames.

headline: Is a ‘Green’ Revolution Poisoning India’s Capital?
abstract: India promised to burn its trash mountains and safely turn them into electricity. But a New York Times investigation found hazardous levels of toxic substances around homes, playgrounds and schools.
lead_paragraph: The trucks have lumbered through the capital for years, dumping loads of hot, acrid ash from thousands of tons of incinerated garbage close to playgrounds and schools.
snippet: India promised to burn its trash mountains and safely turn them into electricity. But a New York Times investigation found hazardous levels of toxic substances around homes, playgrounds and schools.

headline: How Ukraine’s Widows Are Shouldering Their Grief
abstract: It’s impossible to say how many widows the war in Ukraine has created because Kyiv closely guards its casualty figures. But estimates suggest they number in the tens of thousands.
lead_paragraph: As Ukraine’s cemeteries have filled with dead soldiers, a legion of war widows has been growing.
snippet: It’s impossible to say how many widows the war in Ukraine has created because Kyiv closely guards its casualty figures. But estimates suggest they number in the tens of thousands.

headline: He’s a Rock Critic, and a Swiftie. What’s Wrong With That?
abstract: In “Heartbreak Is the National Anthem,” Rob Sheffield chronicles how Taylor Swift has made fans, foes and even journalists part of her story.
lead_paragraph: It’s possible that I know too much about Taylor Swift. I know the words to all her singles and every name on her long list of ex-lovers. Thanks to her current relationship with Travis Kelce, I know details about the various social entanglements of his Kansas City Chiefs teammates that I would prefer not to. I listen to her music about as much as the median American, which is to say: all of the time. Swift has become America’s Muzak, her songs the soundtrack to our Starbucks lines and her life the fodder for our tabloid stories.
snippet: In “Heartbreak Is the National Anthem,” Rob Sheffield chronicles how Taylor Swift has made fans, foes and even journalists part of her story.

headline: They Were Ashamed About Their Debt. Bankruptcy Gave Them a Second Chance.
abstract: Many people who should consider filing for bankruptcy avoid doing so out of shame or fear it could ruin their credit. But it can provide much-needed relief.
lead_paragraph: In my 20s, while attending law school at New York University by day and concerts by night, I racked up over $30,000 in credit card debt. I wasn’t thinking about my credit score; I was solely living in the moment.
snippet: Many people who should consider filing for bankruptcy avoid doing so out of shame or fear it could ruin their credit. But it can provide much-needed relief.

headline: In a Run-Down Movie Theater, She Found a Window on the World
abstract: Esther Kinsky reflects on the nature of seeing in a book about an old cinema in Hungary.
lead_paragraph: “Where in memory is the boundary between images seen and things experienced, as they say, first hand?” This question is the driving force behind “Seeing Further,” the latest book by the German writer and translator Esther Kinsky, whose name is underrecognized among American readers.
snippet: Esther Kinsky reflects on the nature of seeing in a book about an old cinema in Hungary.

headline: A Messy Problem in Orderly Singapore: Keeping Track of Cats
abstract: The reversal of a 35-year ban on cats in public housing won’t be a quick fix for cat-related problems. It’s not even clear how many cats live in the city-state.
lead_paragraph: Xinderella the foster cat has a microchip, a human guardian and a stable home, but she lives in a state of regulatory limbo. Under murky new rules governing cats in Singapore’s public housing, she is not registered to the apartment where she sleeps.
snippet: The reversal of a 35-year ban on cats in public housing won’t be a quick fix for cat-related problems. It’s not even clear how many cats live in the city-state.

headline: A Full-Body Dumbbell Workout You Can Do Anywhere
abstract: Try this beginner-friendly routine to build strength and improve your stability.
lead_paragraph: The dumbbell is one of the oldest pieces of strength training equipment — and it has endured for good reason. With one dumbbell or a pair, you can build a full-body workout that challenges your balance, stability and coordination.
snippet: Try this beginner-friendly routine to build strength and improve your stability.

headline: Need an Arabic-Hebrew Ketubah? This Artist Can Help.
abstract: Josh Berer makes most of his money designing Arabic tattoos. He also has a side business designing cross-cultural marriage contracts.
lead_paragraph: When a couple from Washington, D.C., a Baha’i man and a Jewish woman, married in 2012, they wanted a ketubah, or Jewish decorative marriage contract, that reflected their diverse backgrounds.
snippet: Josh Berer makes most of his money designing Arabic tattoos. He also has a side business designing cross-cultural marriage contracts.

headline: Drinking With the Kids
abstract: Years after bath time and travel soccer, we’re mixing cocktails in the kitchen.
lead_paragraph: Drinking has changed. And nowhere has it changed more than at my house.
snippet: Years after bath time and travel soccer, we’re mixing cocktails in the kitchen.

headline: She Inherited Her Family’s Mansion, the Site of Secret Traumas
abstract: In “The Magnificent Ruins,” an Indian expatriate reunites with her estranged family after her grandfather unexpectedly made her heir to his estate.
lead_paragraph: There’s an adage about mothers and daughters in Anne Carson’s poem “The Glass Essay”: “You remember too much,/my mother said to me recently./Why hold onto all that? And I said,/Where can I put it down?” Such grief, born from the scars of maternal abuse, is both an accusation and an inheritance hiding inside Nayantara Roy’s debut novel, “The Magnificent Ruins.”
snippet: In “The Magnificent Ruins,” an Indian expatriate reunites with her estranged family after her grandfather unexpectedly made her heir to his estate.

headline: Kaley Cuoco Drifts Off to Episodes of ‘Dateline’
abstract: The actress returns for Season 2 of the dark comedy “Based on a True Story” as the true-crime aficionado Ava.
lead_paragraph: When Kaley Cuoco learned she was pregnant before shooting began on the first season of the dark comedy “Based on a True Story,” her character, Ava — a true-crime aficionado on the trail of a serial killer — was given a quick rewrite and became an expectant mother, too.
snippet: The actress returns for Season 2 of the dark comedy “Based on a True Story” as the true-crime aficionado Ava.

headline: This ‘Wall Street Girly’ Wants to Make Wealth More Accessible
abstract: Vivian Tu is one of a new wave of female influencers who are using TikTok and Instagram to spread the message of personal finance to millennials and Generation Z.
lead_paragraph: Back in August, when it looked like the Federal Reserve was about to cut interest rates for the first time in more than four years, Vivian Tu took to TikTok to explain to her roughly 2.6 million followers what that move by the central bank would mean for them.
snippet: Vivian Tu is one of a new wave of female influencers who are using TikTok and Instagram to spread the message of personal finance to millennials and Generation Z.

headline: Is a ‘Green’ Revolution Poisoning India’s Capital?
abstract: An effort to turn India’s trash mountains into energy has become an acute health crisis for a million people in the capital city, New Delhi. Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
lead_paragraph: An effort to turn India’s trash mountains into energy has become an acute health crisis for a million people in the capital city, New Delhi. Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, explains.
snippet: An effort to turn India’s trash mountains into energy has become an acute health crisis for a million people in the capital city, New Delhi. Maria Abi-Habib, an investigative correspondent for The New York Times, explains.

headline: The Lei Makers Reimagining an Ancient Tradition
abstract: A new generation of floral designers is incorporating fresh styles into their creations.
lead_paragraph: When Leilani Pearson, 42, moved to Maui in 2014 with her partner, they inherited his grandparents’ property, along with its 50-year-old gardenia bushes. Sometimes she made necklace leis by stringing the gardenias together using a needle and thread, as is common throughout Hawaii, but often she braided the flowers with lauhala, dried leaves from the hala tree, using techniques more common in Tahiti, where she was born and raised. Before long, she began to incorporate unusual flowers into large, flat, angular leis, setting scarlet lobster claw heliconia or luminescent blue jade vine blossoms or purple-tipped bromeliad flowers in plaits of lauhala.
snippet: A new generation of floral designers is incorporating fresh styles into their creations.

headline: This Taiwanese Calligrapher Brings a Message of Freedom to the Met
abstract: Tong Yang-Tze is reviving an ancient but disappearing practice and making it contemporary — writ large.
lead_paragraph: The boulders hiding in the alcove of Tong Yang-Tze’s apartment testify to this Taiwanese calligrapher’s daunting perfectionism.
snippet: Tong Yang-Tze is reviving an ancient but disappearing practice and making it contemporary — writ large.

headline: How a Sex-Positive Cuban Lesbian Helped Her Creator Play Herself
abstract: In “Give Me Carmelita Tropicana!,” Alina Troyano and her former student Branden Jacobs-Jenkins explore the ways art made by one person can live inside others.
lead_paragraph: You never can tell where your inheritance will come from, but the playwright Branden Jacobs-Jenkins almost missed out on some of his.
snippet: In “Give Me Carmelita Tropicana!,” Alina Troyano and her former student Branden Jacobs-Jenkins explore the ways art made by one person can live inside others.

headline: Do Co-op Board Members Have to Live in the Building?
abstract: And what happens if they don’t?
lead_paragraph: Q: I live in a large Lower Manhattan cooperative with nine board members. One board member has sold their apartment and moved to another state. A second member is living in a foreign country with his family and subletting his apartment, saying he will eventually return to the complex. Both are still serving on the board of directors. I think their ability to work for the best interests of the cooperative could well be compromised. Is this legitimate? What can we do?
snippet: And what happens if they don’t?

headline: Piecing Life Back Together After Helene, One Mud-Splattered Photo at a Time
abstract: The Mosses’ home washed away during the hurricane, and with it went their photos of a son who had died as a child. They didn’t know a determined detective was on the case.
lead_paragraph: Four days after Tommy and Mary Moss watched their home float down the Swannanoa River, the couple and their son Dallas returned to their neighborhood in Asheville, N.C., to begin searching through the mud-caked debris.
snippet: The Mosses’ home washed away during the hurricane, and with it went their photos of a son who had died as a child. They didn’t know a determined detective was on the case.

headline: Low-Profile Donor Makes Big Impact on Los Angeles Arts Groups
abstract: With recent major gifts to several cultural institutions, Jarl Mohn is emerging as an important West Coast philanthropist.
lead_paragraph: Cultural institutions in Los Angeles sometimes bemoan the difficulty of cultivating generous donors who will help fund their operations. Over the last few years, the art collector Jarl Mohn, 72, has emerged as an exception.
snippet: With recent major gifts to several cultural institutions, Jarl Mohn is emerging as an important West Coast philanthropist.

headline: Are Seed Oils Actually Bad for You?
abstract: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others claim they’re harming our health, but the evidence suggests otherwise.
lead_paragraph: To their many vocal detractors, they’re referred to as “the hateful eight.” Canola oil, corn oil, sunflower oil and other refined oils made from the seeds of certain plants have become lightning rods for wellness influencers — and some politicians.
snippet: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. and others claim they’re harming our health, but the evidence suggests otherwise.

headline: Was Wallis Simpson Really a Sex-Crazed Spy?
abstract: As Paul French argues in a new biography, the future Duchess of Windsor’s year in China was less lurid — and more interesting — than her critics knew.
lead_paragraph: Much has been written about Wallis Simpson, the American socialite for whose love King Edward VIII abdicated the throne in 1936. Her eccentric and expensive tastes often demanded attention — who can forget her army of pug pillows or the gold-plated bathtub at their French villa? — but she was also derided as quite ordinary. Cecil Beaton once described her hands as “utilitarian-looking.”
snippet: As Paul French argues in a new biography, the future Duchess of Windsor’s year in China was less lurid — and more interesting — than her critics knew.

headline: Dwight Yoakam, Country Rebel, Has a New Attitude
abstract: At 68, the Nashville outsider is releasing his first album of original material in nearly a decade, inspired by a joyous shift in his personal life.
lead_paragraph: With the sun setting over the vast expanse of Los Angeles, Dwight Yoakam sighed softly as tears rolled down his cheeks. For a moment, the scene played like one of his own portraits of honky-tonk heartache and regret. But sitting in the country star’s 12th-story offices above the Sunset Strip, it became clear that the emotion gripping him was not sadness, but joy.
snippet: At 68, the Nashville outsider is releasing his first album of original material in nearly a decade, inspired by a joyous shift in his personal life.

headline: America’s Split Screen on Abortion
abstract: The abortion rights movement won in many states — even some that voted for Donald Trump. Where does it go from here?
lead_paragraph: In the first few elections after the Supreme Court’s 2022 reversal of Roe v. Wade, the abortion rights movement created reason for hope among its supporters: It won a string of unexpected victories in ballot measures from conservative states like Kansas and Ohio to moderate ones like Michigan.
snippet: The abortion rights movement won in many states — even some that voted for Donald Trump. Where does it go from here?

headline: How We Found the Dangers Threatening Delhi’s ‘Green’ Energy Future
abstract: In the heart of India’s capital, residents blame chronic, debilitating illnesses on an industrial plant burning the city’s garbage and turning it into electricity.
lead_paragraph: We climbed rooftops and set up machines — each the size of a refrigerator — to take samples of the smoke billowing our way.
snippet: In the heart of India’s capital, residents blame chronic, debilitating illnesses on an industrial plant burning the city’s garbage and turning it into electricity.

headline: Elon Musk Is Positioning X Behind the New Trump Presidency
abstract: Since the election, Mr. Musk has used his social media company to talk up how bright the future will be under the president-elect.
lead_paragraph: Since Donald J. Trump won the presidential election, Elon Musk has gone all in on X to promote the incoming administration.
snippet: Since the election, Mr. Musk has used his social media company to talk up how bright the future will be under the president-elect.

headline: Drop-Off in Democratic Votes Ignites Conspiracy Theories on Left and Right
abstract: There is nothing suspicious about the shift in Democratic fortunes. But partisans from across the spectrum are questioning the results, for different reasons.
lead_paragraph: When President-elect Donald J. Trump was announced the winner of this year’s presidential contest on Wednesday, the vote tallies initially suggested a sharp drop-off of millions of Democratic votes compared with the results in 2020.
snippet: There is nothing suspicious about the shift in Democratic fortunes. But partisans from across the spectrum are questioning the results, for different reasons.

headline: Big Tech’s Hotbeds of Employee Activism Quiet After Trump’s Victory
abstract: Eight years ago, workers loudly protested White House policies. This time around, the companies are trying to keep a lid on activism.
lead_paragraph: If any industry could have said its workplaces were politicized, it was tech.
snippet: Eight years ago, workers loudly protested White House policies. This time around, the companies are trying to keep a lid on activism.

headline: Harris Had a Wall Street-Approved Economic Pitch. It Fell Flat.
abstract: The vice president vacillated on how to talk about the economy, and ended up adopting marginal pro-business tweaks that both corporate and progressive allies agreed made for a muddled message.
lead_paragraph: When Vice President Kamala Harris traveled to a locally owned brewery in New Hampshire to talk about helping small businesses — a major plank of her economic platform — she made sure that one group of Americans felt included: millionaires who wanted to keep more of their profits from selling stocks and real estate.
snippet: The vice president vacillated on how to talk about the economy, and ended up adopting marginal pro-business tweaks that both corporate and progressive allies agreed made for a muddled message.

headline: An Earthling Tunes In to a Hidden Universal Message
abstract: Wonderful ideas are available to all of us, says the singer-songwriter Beverly Glenn-Copeland, a terrestrial fellow traveler.
snippet: Wonderful ideas are available to all of us, says the singer-songwriter Beverly Glenn-Copeland, a terrestrial fellow traveler.

headline: 58 Movies to Watch This Winter: Bob Dylan Biopic, ‘Moana 2’ and More
abstract: From life stories (“A Complete Unknown,” “The Fire Inside”) to animated tales (“Moana 2,” “Mufasa”), these are the films we can’t wait to see this season.
lead_paragraph: ‘EMILIA PÉREZ’ Four actresses — Zoe Saldaña, Karla Sofía Gascón, Selena Gomez and Adriana Paz — shared a prize at Cannes for their performances in this unlikeliest of musicals, about the friendship between a Mexican cartel kingpin (Gascón) and a lawyer (Saldaña) hired to arrange the kingpin’s gender transition. Jacques Audiard directed. (Nov. 13; Netflix)
snippet: From life stories (“A Complete Unknown,” “The Fire Inside”) to animated tales (“Moana 2,” “Mufasa”), these are the films we can’t wait to see this season.

headline: Biden and Environmental Groups Try to Protect Climate Policies from Trump
abstract: John Podesta, President Biden’s clean energy adviser, said agencies were racing to deliver money from the 2022 climate law before Donald Trump arrives.
lead_paragraph: Biden administration aides are racing to award hundreds of millions of dollars in grants and finalize environmental regulations in an effort to lock in President Biden’s climate agenda before Donald J. Trump enters the White House, said John Podesta, the president’s senior adviser on clean energy.
snippet: John Podesta, President Biden’s clean energy adviser, said agencies were racing to deliver money from the 2022 climate law before Donald Trump arrives.

headline: Trump Has Made His View of Migrants Clear. Will It Stop Them From Coming?
abstract: The incoming president has promised the largest deportation effort in U.S. history. Now migrants are weighing a new Trump administration in deciding whether to trek to the United States.
lead_paragraph: This Sunday was the day that Daniel García, a Venezuelan delivery worker living in the capital of Colombia, had planned to begin an arduous land journey toward the United States.
snippet: The incoming president has promised the largest deportation effort in U.S. history. Now migrants are weighing a new Trump administration in deciding whether to trek to the United States.

headline: Trump Holds Up Transition Process Over Ethics Code
abstract: President-elect Donald J. Trump has not submitted a required ethics plan stating he will avoid conflicts of interest.
lead_paragraph: President-elect Donald J. Trump has not yet submitted a legally required ethics pledge stating that he will avoid conflicts of interest and other ethical concerns while in office, raising concerns that his refusal to do so will hamper the smooth transition to power.
snippet: President-elect Donald J. Trump has not submitted a required ethics plan stating he will avoid conflicts of interest.

headline: Should Alito and Thomas Be Pushed to Retire? Conservatives Are Divided.
abstract: Coaxing aging Supreme Court justices to give up their power and status during a window of political opportunity can be a delicate endeavor.
lead_paragraph: With Republicans set to regain control of the White House and the Senate, the spotlight has turned to the Supreme Court and whether the two oldest justices may step down, paving the way for President-elect Donald J. Trump to lock down a conservative supermajority for years.
snippet: Coaxing aging Supreme Court justices to give up their power and status during a window of political opportunity can be a delicate endeavor.

headline: 5 Takeaways From Nancy Pelosi’s Interview With The New York Times
abstract: In her first extended interview after the election, the former House speaker was not interested in analyzing Democratic losses and was eager to put a sunny spin on the future.
lead_paragraph: After the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Nancy Pelosi made it known that she would do everything she could to prevent Donald Trump from becoming president again. Pelosi, who was both minority leader and House speaker during Trump’s first term, was reportedly instrumental in persuading President Biden to end his candidacy over the summer. Like most Democrats, she rallied around Kamala Harris and, as late as the night before the election, projected confidence that Harris would win on Tuesday. That didn’t pan out.
snippet: In her first extended interview after the election, the former House speaker was not interested in analyzing Democratic losses and was eager to put a sunny spin on the future.

headline: Nancy Pelosi Insists the Election Was Not a Rebuke of the Democrats
abstract: The former House Speaker reflects on Donald Trump’s victory, Kamala Harris’s candidacy and the future of the Democratic Party.
lead_paragraph: Perhaps no Democratic politician has been a greater antagonist to Donald Trump than Nancy Pelosi. As the House minority leader and then speaker of the House during Trump’s first term, she participated in two Trump impeachments, memorably ripped up a copy of Trump’s State of the Union address after he delivered it and was targeted by an angry mob during the attack on the Capitol on Jan. 6. Pelosi vowed to never allow Trump back in the White House for another term. By all accounts, she was a key voice in persuading Biden to end his campaign this summer and give another Democrat a shot at beating Trump.
snippet: The former House Speaker reflects on Donald Trump’s victory, Kamala Harris’s candidacy and the future of the Democratic Party.

headline: Russia Sentences Soldiers Over Killing of Ukrainian Family
abstract: The case, in which two soldiers murdered nine members of a family after breaking into their home, was a rare prosecution over crimes against civilians in Ukraine.
lead_paragraph: A court in Russia has sentenced two Russian soldiers to life in prison for killing a family of nine after breaking into their home in occupied Ukraine, a rare legal case against atrocities committed by Moscow’s soldiers in the war.
snippet: The case, in which two soldiers murdered nine members of a family after breaking into their home, was a rare prosecution over crimes against civilians in Ukraine.

headline: Train Station Suicide Bombing Leaves Dozens Dead or Wounded in Pakistan
abstract: A banned ethnic separatist group in a restive province claimed responsibility for the deadly attack in Quetta, the provincial capital.
lead_paragraph: At least two dozen people were killed and more than 40 others wounded in a suicide bombing at a train station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta on Saturday morning, officials said.
snippet: A banned ethnic separatist group in a restive province claimed responsibility for the deadly attack in Quetta, the provincial capital.

headline: The Connections Companion No. 518
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Nov. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Good morning, dear connectors. Welcome to today’s Connections forum, where you can give and receive puzzle — and emotional — support.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Sunday, Nov. 10, 2024.

headline: Wordle Review No. 1,240
abstract: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 10, 2024.
lead_paragraph: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This page contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
snippet: Scroll down for hints and conversation about the puzzle for Nov. 10, 2024.

headline: Canada Sends Mixed Signals With TikTok Shutdown Order
abstract: The industry minister closed TikTok’s offices in Toronto and Vancouver over security concerns, but Canadians can still download and use the app.
lead_paragraph: This week Canada shut down TikTok — but not in the way that some people had been expecting.
snippet: The industry minister closed TikTok’s offices in Toronto and Vancouver over security concerns, but Canadians can still download and use the app.

headline: Playing Favorites
abstract: The foods and music and culture that move us most might not be very good, but that doesn’t diminish their power to comfort and delight.
lead_paragraph: Last month, The Times published a list of New York’s 25 best pizza places. Like any good New Yorker, I made sure my favorite pie was on the list, then vowed to find a new favorite. There’s pleasure in having one’s tastes affirmed by the tastemakers. Then there’s the even sweeter satisfaction of liking something no one else has discovered yet — a vanishingly rare experience in the TikTok era, when influencers trumpet their “secret” spots to eager followers and the next thing you know, there’s a line around the block at your neighborhood bakery.
snippet: The foods and music and culture that move us most might not be very good, but that doesn’t diminish their power to comfort and delight.

headline: U.N.-Backed Panel Warns Action Needed in Days to Avert Gaza Famine
abstract: The warning focused on the north comes as the Biden administration has set a mid-November deadline for Israel to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or face a cutoff of weapons aid.
lead_paragraph: A United Nations-backed panel has warned that famine is imminent in the northern Gaza Strip, days before a deadline imposed on Israel by the Biden administration to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or risk a cutoff of military aid.
snippet: The warning focused on the north comes as the Biden administration has set a mid-November deadline for Israel to deliver more humanitarian supplies to the enclave or face a cutoff of weapons aid.

headline: Amsterdam Bars Protests After Antisemitic Attacks on Soccer Fans
abstract: The violence erupted around a soccer match between Israeli and Dutch teams in Amsterdam on Thursday.
lead_paragraph: Amsterdam banned demonstrations over the weekend under an emergency order and mobilized additional police officers after what city officials described as antisemitic attacks on Israeli soccer fans during the week.
snippet: The violence erupted around a soccer match between Israeli and Dutch teams in Amsterdam on Thursday.

headline: The Book That Predicted the 2024 Election
abstract: The G.O.P. pollster Patrick Ruffini’s book “Party of the People” outlined the realignments reflected in this year’s election results.
lead_paragraph: This is an edited transcript of an episode of “The Ezra Klein Show.” You can listen to the conversation by following or subscribing on the NYT Audio App, Apple, Spotify, Amazon Music, YouTube, iHeartRadio or wherever you get your podcasts.
snippet: The G.O.P. pollster Patrick Ruffini’s book “Party of the People” outlined the realignments reflected in this year’s election results.

headline: A.I. Companions and the Mental Health Risks for the Young
abstract: Readers discuss an article about a teenager’s suicide.
lead_paragraph: To the Editor:
snippet: Readers discuss an article about a teenager’s suicide.

headline: Maybe Now Democrats Will Address Working-Class Pain
abstract: Democrats can compete if they focus more on minimum wages and child care than pronouns and purity.
lead_paragraph: The other day I was supposed to visit a friend who had been released from prison. He had to cancel to rescue his sister, who is using drugs again.
snippet: Democrats can compete if they focus more on minimum wages and child care than pronouns and purity.

headline: Scenes From America on the Edge, Partying and Despairing
abstract: Election night and the day after, 2024.
lead_paragraph: The election results came a lot faster than most people expected. On Tuesday it was just voting and waiting and anxiety and an inner sense that anything was possible and then by Wednesday morning, one answer: Donald Trump had shifted the country toward him in a decisive win.
snippet: Election night and the day after, 2024.

headline: This Is All Biden’s Fault
abstract: Biden too often could not find the best way to help Democrats win.
lead_paragraph: Kamala Harris lost the election this week, but I mostly don’t blame her. At least, I don’t blame her because of anything she did recently. Since she became the unofficial nominee in July, she played a difficult hand about as well as she could have, running a disciplined campaign that sought to reassure Americans about the economic issues that trouble them most, in a political environment that was very rough for Democrats and for incumbent parties around the world.
snippet: Biden too often could not find the best way to help Democrats win.

headline: The Elites Had It Coming
abstract: Democrats got exactly what they set out to get, and now here we are.
lead_paragraph: Everyone has a moment when he first realized that Donald Trump might well return, and here is mine. It was back in March, during a visit to the Smithsonian’s National Portrait Gallery, when I happened to read the explanatory text beside an old painting. This note described the westward advance of the United States in the 19th century as “settler colonialism.” I read it, and I knew instantly where this nation was going.
snippet: Democrats got exactly what they set out to get, and now here we are.

headline: Trump Is About to Face the Choice That Dooms Many Presidencies
abstract: Electoral success has a thousand fathers, each with his own agenda.
lead_paragraph: As happens every time a new president is elected, Donald Trump is experiencing a sudden role reversal. His campaign to earn support from voters has ended abruptly and a new one has begun among donors and activists to earn his support for their priorities. The election was about tax cuts, or maybe cryptocurrency, the arguments go. What Americans really want, sir, is fewer protections on the job and a weaker safety net.
snippet: Electoral success has a thousand fathers, each with his own agenda.

headline: Democrats and the Case of Mistaken Identity Politics
abstract: The post mortem is a wake for woke.
lead_paragraph: Some Democrats are finally waking up and realizing that woke is broke.
snippet: The post mortem is a wake for woke.

headline: Could the Bond Market Stymie Trump’s Economic Plans?
abstract: Some fiscal hawks worry that Trump’s policies would increase the deficit and fuel inflation.
lead_paragraph: With Republicans poised to seize control of Congress, Donald Trump’s economic plans could face little legislative resistance. The president-elect has vowed to escalate tariffs, extend a corporate tax cut and introduce tax breaks on tips and Social Security benefits, policies that some fiscal hawks worry would increase the federal deficit, and with it, inflation.
snippet: Some fiscal hawks worry that Trump’s policies would increase the deficit and fuel inflation.

headline: A Banker Is Scouting Trump’s Nominees. Some Will Oversee His Interests.
abstract: Howard Lutnick, co-chair of the president-elect’s transition team and a Wall Street financier, is leading the search for appointees while still running his businesses.
lead_paragraph: The financier Howard Lutnick has been given a high-profile assignment from President-elect Donald J. Trump, one that raises questions about the Wall Street executive’s dual role and what he might gain from it.
snippet: Howard Lutnick, co-chair of the president-elect’s transition team and a Wall Street financier, is leading the search for appointees while still running his businesses.

headline: Bacon Defeats Vargas in Nebraska, Holding a Key House Seat for Republicans
abstract: The victory of the four-term Republican, who has resisted his party’s veer to the right, dashed Democratic hopes of flipping a critical district.
lead_paragraph: Representative Don Bacon of Nebraska, one of the most politically vulnerable Republicans in the country, has defeated his Democratic challenger and won a fifth term, according to The Associated Press. His victory denies Democrats one of their best opportunities this year to pick up a seat and bolsters his party’s drive to hold its majority.
snippet: The victory of the four-term Republican, who has resisted his party’s veer to the right, dashed Democratic hopes of flipping a critical district.

headline: Weeds Are Everywhere. Why Aren’t We Eating Them More?
abstract: Fast-growing and prolific, these plants are the next frontier in foraging.
lead_paragraph: Copenhagen’s Noma restaurant may have introduced foraging into fine dining, but the concept was hardly a new one: Every culture has its own tradition of gathering wild ingredients, from bamboo shoots in Bhutan to lingonberries in Sweden to gemsbok beans in the Kalahari Desert.
snippet: Fast-growing and prolific, these plants are the next frontier in foraging.

headline: Easy Hand-Pulled Noodles (With Video!)
abstract: This wonderfully doable recipe from Vivian Chan-Tam is a fun bit of kitchen craft time.
lead_paragraph: I’m a pretty fidgety person — apologies to everyone seated in front of me on planes whom I’ve accidentally bumped — so for me, a cooking project is just as much about the finished dish as it is all the handiwork that goes into it. I love folding dumplings, caramelizing onions, wrapping enchiladas, massaging kimchi, rolling meatballs. This “keep my hands busy” philosophy is the same reason I got into knitting. But you can’t eat a sweater, even if it’s knit in brioche stitch.
snippet: This wonderfully doable recipe from Vivian Chan-Tam is a fun bit of kitchen craft time.

headline: At Least Two Dozen People Killed in Suicide Bombing in Pakistan
abstract: The Baloch Liberation Army, a banned ethnic separatist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a railway station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta.
lead_paragraph: The Baloch Liberation Army, a banned ethnic separatist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a railway station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta.
snippet: The Baloch Liberation Army, a banned ethnic separatist group, claimed responsibility for the attack, which occurred at a railway station in the southwestern Pakistani city of Quetta.

headline: Biden and Trump to Meet at White House on Wednesday
abstract: President Biden extended the invitation to his former rival as part of a longstanding tradition to help ease the transition to a new administration.
lead_paragraph: President Biden will host President-elect Donald J. Trump at the White House on Wednesday, extending a presidential tradition to his onetime rival that Mr. Trump did not offer four years ago after Mr. Biden defeated him.
snippet: President Biden extended the invitation to his former rival as part of a longstanding tradition to help ease the transition to a new administration.

headline: What Do Trump Voters Know About the Future He Has Planned for Them?
abstract: Be careful what you wish for, Part 99.
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday, Donald Trump became the first Republican in 20 years to win the national popular vote and the Electoral College.
snippet: Be careful what you wish for, Part 99.

headline: Overlooked No More: Go-won-go Mohawk, Trailblazing Indigenous Actress
abstract: In the 1880s, the only roles for Indigenous performers were laden with negative stereotypes. So Mohawk decided to write her own narratives.
lead_paragraph: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.
snippet: In the 1880s, the only roles for Indigenous performers were laden with negative stereotypes. So Mohawk decided to write her own narratives.

headline: Qatar Pauses Role as Mediator in Gaza Cease-Fire Talks, Citing Deadlock
abstract: The Qatari Foreign Ministry announced it had stepped back from talks, saying it would resume once Israel and Hamas “show willingness and seriousness.”
lead_paragraph: Qatar, a key mediator between Israel and Hamas, announced on Saturday night that it had paused its efforts to broker a cease-fire between the two sides to end the war in Gaza, citing the deadlock in talks.
snippet: The Qatari Foreign Ministry announced it had stepped back from talks, saying it would resume once Israel and Hamas “show willingness and seriousness.”

headline: Kenneth Bronstein, Who Put His Faith in Atheism, Dies at 85
abstract: The organization that he led advocated the separation of church and state, with no exceptions for holidays, currency, symbolism or blessings.
lead_paragraph: Kenneth Bronstein recalled the first meeting of NYC Atheists that he organized. “It was sad,” he told The Washington Post in 2004. “Ten guys in a room, all arguing with each other.”
snippet: The organization that he led advocated the separation of church and state, with no exceptions for holidays, currency, symbolism or blessings.

headline: FEMA Fires Employee for Telling Milton Relief Workers to Skip Houses With Trump Signs
abstract: The agency said it was investigating the incident in the aftermath of the Category 3 hurricane that hit Florida in October.
lead_paragraph: An employee with the Federal Emergency Management Agency has been fired after reports that in the aftermath of Hurricane Milton, the employee told relief workers in Florida to pass over houses with signs supporting Donald J. Trump, the agency said Saturday.
snippet: The agency said it was investigating the incident in the aftermath of the Category 3 hurricane that hit Florida in October.

headline: Government Moves to Thwart Guilty Plea Proceedings in Sept. 11 Case
abstract: Prosecutors plan to appeal the trial judge’s ruling that the defense secretary had not lawfully rescinded the government plea deal with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.
lead_paragraph: War court prosecutors are asking a military judge to refrain from taking guilty pleas from Khalid Shaikh Mohammed, who is accused of masterminding the Sept. 11 attacks, and from two men accused of conspiring with him until a higher court decides the validity of their plea agreements.
snippet: Prosecutors plan to appeal the trial judge’s ruling that the defense secretary had not lawfully rescinded the government plea deal with Khalid Shaikh Mohammed.

headline: Trevor Sorbie, Known for the Dorothy Hamill ‘Wedge’ Cut, Dies at 75
abstract: He also styled hair for Helen Mirren, the Beach Boys and others, and he was honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to British hairdressing.
lead_paragraph: Trevor Sorbie, a celebrity hairstylist who is widely credited with creating the “wedge” cut made popular by the figure skater Dorothy Hamill, and whose scrunch drying method became widely used in the 1980s, died on Friday at his home in Fareham, England. He was 75.
snippet: He also styled hair for Helen Mirren, the Beach Boys and others, and he was honored by Queen Elizabeth II for services to British hairdressing.

headline: Smoky Smell Engulfs New York City After Fires in Brooklyn and New Jersey
abstract: New Yorkers encountered an unsettling smell on Saturday, a day after fires broke out in Prospect Park and across the Hudson River.
lead_paragraph: The smell of acrid smoke spread throughout New York City on Saturday and persisted into the evening, after brush fires broke out on Friday in Brooklyn, the Bronx and nearby New Jersey. It was a surreal experience for a city that is rarely home to wildfires but is in the middle of a drought.
snippet: New Yorkers encountered an unsettling smell on Saturday, a day after fires broke out in Prospect Park and across the Hudson River.

headline: Tony Todd, Prolific Actor Best Known for ‘Candyman,’ Dies at 69
abstract: Mr. Todd’s decades-long career spanned across mediums and genres, but he was largely associated with a scary figure summoned in front of a mirror.
lead_paragraph: Tony Todd, a prolific actor whose more than 100 film and television credits included the horror movie franchises “Candyman,” in which he played the vicious title character, and “Final Destination,” died on Wednesday at his home in Los Angeles. He was 69.
snippet: Mr. Todd’s decades-long career spanned across mediums and genres, but he was largely associated with a scary figure summoned in front of a mirror.

headline: Baltazar Ushca, Who Kept Andean Ice Harvesting Alive, Dies at 80
abstract: He trekked up Ecuador’s tallest mountain twice a week for six decades to hack ice off a glacier with a pickax. He is believed to have been the last of his breed.
lead_paragraph: For 60 years, Baltazar Ushca worked a rare but rigorous trade: ice merchant. Once or twice a week, he climbed snow-capped Mount Chimborazo, Ecuador’s highest peak, to hack ice from a glacier with a pickax, wrap the 60-pound blocks in hay and transport them on the backs of his donkeys. He would then sell them to villagers who did not have electricity and needed refrigeration to conserve their food.
snippet: He trekked up Ecuador’s tallest mountain twice a week for six decades to hack ice off a glacier with a pickax. He is believed to have been the last of his breed.

headline: From Start to Finish
abstract: Sam Ezersky’s Sunday puzzle flips the script.
lead_paragraph: Jump to: Tricky Clues | Today’s Theme
snippet: Sam Ezersky’s Sunday puzzle flips the script.

headline: At Women’s March Event, Organizers Say They Are Preparing a ‘Comeback Tour’
abstract: At a demonstration on Saturday, the crowd was small and enthusiasm was lacking. But organizers are planning a big march ahead of the inauguration.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday, after former President Donald J. Trump’s re-election dashed progressives’ hopes of a new era for women’s rights and other left-wing causes, Women’s March held a hastily arranged protest-cum-dance party outside the headquarters of a conservative think tank in Washington. Only about a few hundred people showed up.
snippet: At a demonstration on Saturday, the crowd was small and enthusiasm was lacking. But organizers are planning a big march ahead of the inauguration.

headline: Judith Jamison, Alvin Ailey Dancer of ‘Power and Radiance,’ Dies at 81
abstract: She became an international star as a member of the company and later directed it, guiding it out of debt and boosting its popularity.
lead_paragraph: Judith Jamison, who became an international star with Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater, first as a majestic dancer and then as the troupe’s director, building it into the most successful modern dance company in the country, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 81.
snippet: She became an international star as a member of the company and later directed it, guiding it out of debt and boosting its popularity.

headline: Two Militia Founders Are Convicted of Plot to Kill Federal Agents
abstract: “We were going out huntin’,” one of the men said in a video before a planned trip to the Mexico border, where they intended to shoot at immigrants and officials who might stop them, prosecutors said.
lead_paragraph: Two founders of a militia group who were plotting a trip to the U.S.-Mexico border to shoot at immigrants and the authorities who might try to stop them were convicted on Thursday by a federal jury in Missouri of attempting to murder federal agents, prosecutors said.
snippet: “We were going out huntin’,” one of the men said in a video before a planned trip to the Mexico border, where they intended to shoot at immigrants and officials who might stop them, prosecutors said.
